disease: Symptomatic late syphilis of other respiratory organs

symptoms.name: Rash
symptoms.pattern: Three weeks duration, forehead, trunk, palms, and soles

symptoms.name: Cough
symptoms.pattern: Mentioned as a possible symptom in general description of pulmonary syphilis

symptoms.name: Hemoptysis
symptoms.pattern: Mentioned as a possible symptom in general description of pulmonary syphilis

symptoms.name: Dyspnea
symptoms.pattern: Mentioned as a possible symptom in general description of pulmonary syphilis

physical_findings: Macular rash predominantly on trunk and soles of feet, occasional scattered lesions on palms
Normal cardiovascular, respiratory, and abdominal examinations

lab_values.skin biopsy: perivascular and interstitial mixed infiltrate of plasma cells with focal collections of histiocytes and giant cells. No organisms seen on Ziehl-Neelsen staining; dark-field microscopy not performed. PCR positive for syphilis (bmp, tpp-47, and polA genes).

risk_factors: Sexually active with one male partner who had previously been treated for sexually transmitted infections

imaging_findings.chest radiograph: 1.5-cm rounded opacity in the left middle to lower lobe of her lung
imaging_findings.CT scan: Four necrotic-appearing nodules in the right middle lobe and both lower lobes of the lungs (6–29 mm in diameter). Almost complete resolution three months after treatment.

required: Positive serologic tests for syphilis (e.g., EIA, RPR, TPPA)
Characteristic clinical presentation (e.g., rash, chest pain, etc.)
Imaging findings consistent with pulmonary syphilis (e.g., nodules)
supportive: Positive PCR for syphilis in tissue sample
